title: How personal should my college essay be? - Quora

response.answer_text: When writing a college essay, prompts will tell you what to write. Often, the essay prompt tells the students to indicate why they want to join the college. Sometimes, colleges prefer to include non-conventional essay prompts to test the student’s creativity. A college essay about your desire to get admitted should document your life experiences. However, there is a limit to how personal your college essay can be. What should I include in my college essay? Despite the need to tell your life story, you should try not to ‘overshare’ with the admission board. Talk about mutual benefits Indicate what you can offer the college in exchange for the opportunity to acquire your degree with them. It is essential to discuss all the research opportunities you wish to explore and why the institution is the best fit for you. Discuss your academic achievements If you have participated in any national or regional competitions in high school, you should include them in your essay. Participating in STEM competitions and Olympiads will bear testament to your academic prowess. Mention your life challenges Your prospects at admission will increase if you mention hurdles you had to overcome in your personal life. For students from low-income households, writing about your challenges to make ends meet will help your chances of gaining admission. Don’t overshare Always remember that the admissions committee members are not your buddies. You don’t have to share any stories regarding your political views or sexual experiences. Authenticity is everything, but there are no benefits to keeping it too real. Adjust the tone of your paper Your college essay can be successful if you use a semi-formal tone. Proofread the final copy and get rid of any phrases that might suggest familiarity with the board. You can get personal in your college essay, but you should filter the information you share with the committee.

As personal as it can get without destroying the sanctity of the question/topic. Personal experiences provide admission committees a glimpse into your journey so far and evaluate whether your decisions are coherent with your aims and goals. It also is a good way to relate to the challenges different candidates face in their journey. However it should be ensured that the objectivity of the question or the topic is not lot in unnecessary details and the examiner does not have to go through an endless stream of life events.  What personalization also does is that it gives an element of uniqueness to the essay given that most essays will involve familiar themes around educational background and future ambitions. You need to be as personal as you want to be, in the essay you need to show up your personal qualities and you don’t need to tear you soul with bad memories for it. Use a proofreading on some site like this https://myessaywriting.co.uk/admission-essay.html and make your essay actually perfect, if you wish, but don’t open your heart for some task if you don’t want to. In case, you’re not really hurt because of these hard times, then you could write about it for showing a strength of character, but don’t make it too much. As in every essay, try to show yourself in the good light, but still - don’t make it too much, because you should not be arrogant.

To be honest, the college admissions people don't really care. There are the occasional essays that move them in one way or another, but that is generally because of the quality of the writing, not the content. You could write very artfully about something completely mundane and have a gamechanging essay, or you could take a very personal experience and have mediocre writing. It really doesn't matter what you write about. They want to see how you think and react to situations in your life.

If you have a story where you've demonstrated strength of character and persistance in overcoming hard times, that can be a good college essay.  I would avoid stories where you come off only as a victim.  You're looking for respect, not pity, from the reviewer.  If there are topics that are too emotional for you to write about, I would avoid those and pick something less stressful.  You primarily want the essay to be well-structured and well-written, so I recommend getting a draft together and having one or more people read it and give feedback.

Part of the purpose of college admissions essays is for the admissions committee to learn about you as a person. How have you affected others? How have others affected you? So, talking about overcoming adversity can be a good topic for an essay. Just be careful to avoid topics that are inherently controversial, where the reader might react more to your position on the topic than your writing. Writing about politics or religion, for example, is always risky.

However personal you want to make it.  I think you might err on the side of personal because it demonstrates self-knowledge and interesting writing. Plus being honest ideally should serve you in a process that is about finding the right fit for your education.

It can be as personal as you want, as long as you are comfortable with sharing it. The admission officers just want to learn more about you and to see if you are a good fit for the school & if that specific school is the best place for you.

Women! Whatever you do, don’t write about your abortion. I knew a woman — liberal, pro-choice — who was on her college’s committee to evaluate admissions essays. I heard her say once, “If I have to read one more essay about an abortion, I’m going to scream!”

Do not focus your essay exclusively on how hard it's been for you, but you can focus on how you have overcome those hard times. You can mention those hard times - economic adversity, psychological abuse, or whatever - but then describe the coping strategies you have used, which should include the desire to excel in academics with the goal of becoming a productive member of society, making a larger contribution, etc...
